title: Haloacetic acids - vol. NaOH to reach equivalence

content.question: A student titrates <math alttext="10.0 milliliter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> samples of <math alttext="1.0 molar " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext></mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> solutions of each of the haloacetic acids with a standard solution of <math alttext="N a O H " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following statements correctly predicts the volume of <math alttext="N a O H, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> needed to reach the equivalence point?

choices.label: Fluoroacetic acid will need the smallest volume of <math alttext="N a O H, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> to reach the equivalence point.

Iodoacetic acid will need the smallest volume of <math alttext="N a O H, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> to reach the equivalence point.

All of the acids will need the same volume of <math alttext="N a O H, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> to reach the equivalence point.
All of the haloacetic acids are weak; therefore none will reach an equivalence point.

content.answer: All of the acids will need the same volume of <math alttext="N a O H, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> to reach the equivalence point.

skill.text: 4.A: Predict and/or explain chemical properties or phenomena (e.g., of atoms or molecules) using given chemical theories, models, and representations.
